articles.headline: U.S. Importers and Greek Suppliers Stymied by Cash Controls
articles.snippet: American importers of Greek products are stymied by their suppliers’ inability to procure materials for export.
articles.abstract: American importers of Greek products are stymied by their suppliers’ inability to procure materials for export.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ted Diamantis, an importer of Greek wines who is based in Chicago, has been helping his suppliers stock up on bottles, labels and printing ink. The barrels, though, have him worried.

articles.headline: Chris Christie’s Personality Is Selling Point, but New Hampshire May Not Be Buying
articles.snippet: In interviews, Republican officials and voters expressed concern about Mr. Christie’s brushes with controversy at home, as well as his personality.
articles.abstract: In interviews, Republican officials and voters expressed concern about Mr. Christie’s brushes with controversy at home, as well as his personality.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — He flew to this state immediately after announcing his presidential candidacy and burned nearly a half-million dollars on his initial ad purchase, directed at voters here. He has locked down the former state Republican chairman to lead his New Hampshire campaign. And he has already held more than a dozen town-hall-style events in the state.

articles.headline: University of Cincinnati Officer Indicted in Shooting Death of Samuel Dubose
articles.snippet: The officer, Ray Tensing, is accused of killing Mr. Dubose, who was unarmed, during a traffic stop on July 19.
articles.abstract: The officer, Ray Tensing, is accused of killing Mr. Dubose, who was unarmed, during a traffic stop on July 19.
articles.lead_paragraph: A University of Cincinnati police officer was indicted Wednesday on a murder charge in what a prosecutor called “a senseless, asinine shooting” of an unarmed man during a minor traffic stop. Officials say it was the first time such a charge had been leveled against an officer in the county.

articles.headline: September Is Looking Likelier for Fed’s First Rate Increase
articles.snippet: The central bank was upbeat, saying that while growth remained disappointing by historical standards, the economy was expanding moderately.
articles.abstract: The central bank was upbeat, saying that while growth remained disappointing by historical standards, the economy was expanding moderately.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve remains on track to raise interest rates later this year, and perhaps as soon as its next policy meeting in mid-September, as economic growth continues to meet its expectations.

articles.headline: Hunt for California Girl Leads to a Body, and a Neighbor, 15
articles.snippet: An idyllic artists’ colony at the edge of Santa Cruz, Calif., was thrust into a harsh reality with the killing of an 8-year-old girl.
articles.abstract: An idyllic artists’ colony at the edge of Santa Cruz, Calif., was thrust into a harsh reality with the killing of an 8-year-old girl.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — At the edge of this coastal California town known for its liberal bent and boardwalk amusement park is a cluster of big red barnlike structures that was supposed to be a freewheeling utopia of its own.

articles.headline: Facebook Posts Solid Gains, a Feat Eluding Rivals
articles.snippet: The social media company reported continued growth in users, with 1.49 billion people logging on at least once a month.
articles.abstract: The social media company reported continued growth in users, with 1.49 billion people logging on at least once a month.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Drama may be exciting, but consistency makes for better performance in the stock market.

articles.headline: Deals Flow to Contractor Tied to Mexican President
articles.snippet: Several recent scandals have tainted the legacy of President Enrique Peña Nieto and further eroded the public’s faith in the country’s governing institutions.
articles.abstract: Several recent scandals have tainted the legacy of President Enrique Peña Nieto and further eroded the public’s faith in the country’s governing institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO XOCHICUAUTLA, Mexico — Armando García has filed lawsuits, joined protests and gotten arrested trying to stop a highway from slicing through his hilly backyard in a nature reserve.
articles.byline: By Paulina Villegas and Frances Robles

articles.headline: A Psychologist as Warden? Jail and Mental Illness Intersect in Chicago
articles.snippet: Dr. Nneka Jones Tapia, a clinical psychologist, was chosen to run Cook County Jail, underscoring how much the nation’s prisons have become holding centers for the mentally ill.
articles.abstract: Dr. Nneka Jones Tapia, a clinical psychologist, was chosen to run Cook County Jail, underscoring how much the nation’s prisons have become holding centers for the mentally ill.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Nneka Jones Tapia, who runs the sprawling Cook County Jail here, has an indelible childhood memory of police officers pounding on the aluminum walls of the family’s double-wide trailer home in North Carolina, riffling through cupboards and drawers, and arresting her father on charges of selling marijuana.

articles.headline: Patent Protection for Drugs Puts Pressure on U.S. in Trade Talks
articles.snippet: No issue in negotiations over a Trans-Pacific Partnership seems to elicit more passion than pharmaceuticals, with both sides using the language of life and death.
articles.abstract: No issue in negotiations over a Trans-Pacific Partnership seems to elicit more passion than pharmaceuticals, with both sides using the language of life and death.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHAINA, Hawaii — With 12 nations pressing to conclude the largest regional trade accord ever, United States officials find themselves squeezed between activists pressing to secure access to low-cost pharmaceuticals and Republicans who say Congress will reject a deal without strong patent protections for the drug industry.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 2.3% Rate in 2nd Quarter
articles.snippet: The rebound, after a discouraging first quarter, was largely expected and continued the slow but steady recovery trajectory of the last six years.
articles.abstract: The rebound, after a discouraging first quarter, was largely expected and continued the slow but steady recovery trajectory of the last six years.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a common pattern of the last few years, the American economy, after a dismal start to 2015, regained its footing in the spring and looked set to continue a modest advance for the rest of the year.

articles.headline: Northern Ireland Town Embraces Beckett Festival
articles.snippet: The Happy Days Enniskillen International Beckett Festival, which opened on July 23 and runs through Monday, offers a festive and buoyant atmosphere.
articles.abstract: The Happy Days Enniskillen International Beckett Festival, which opened on July 23 and runs through Monday, offers a festive and buoyant atmosphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland — Strange white-robed, chalky-faced figures, their eyes outlined with dark circles, shuffle forward in silence, then stand motionless as the low tones of Schubert’s “The Organ Grinder,” from his “Winterreise” song cycle, fill the air. A piercing whistle seems to propel them into movement and they shuffle and stop until another whistle commands them. Who are they? What are they doing? Why?
